w:r.w:t: The teacher will teach basic compound words by using TPR, sentence frames, and vocabulary. Students will study these words and phrases:
goldfish, ladybug, dragonfly, backpack, cupcake, popcorn, inside, outside, I am eating pancakes/popcorn/cupcakes, I se
At completion of this lesson, students will be able to:
Recognize, spell, and pronounce the words for compound words
Spell and pronounce common associated words
Use sets of words in complete sentences
Word List: goldfish, ladybug, dragonfly, backpack, cupcake, popcorn, inside, outside
This slide will always be the
-branded opener slide that the teacher will display as the student enters the classroom.
Greet your student and introduce the lesson concept: “Today, we are going to be learning about compound words!”
Listen to the poem your teacher reads
Listen to the compound words that are in the poem
Read the poem to the student.
Explain that these are two little words put together to make a new word,
Listen to the definition of a compound word.
Circle the two words that are put together to make one new word.
Read the definition of a compound word to the student. Underline pancake and circle
Explain that these are two small words put together (do the action for
by pushing your two hands’ fingertips together).
Tell the child that there are many compound words we see
and we’ll learn the names of them.
Circle the two parts to each word
Say and spell the letters to each compound word
Read the compound words as you underline them. Have the child repeat.
Circle the two little words to each compound word. Clear the screen and have the child repeat.
Say and spell the letters to each compound word. Have the child repeat.
Say the name of each compound word
Spell the compound words in the boxes.
Read the name of each compound word and have the child repeat.
Encourage the child to spell the words in the boxes provided.

Circle the two little words to each compound word. Clear the screen and have the child repeat.
Read the passage with the support of your teacher.
Find the compound words you learned and some new compound words.
Read the passage or, if the child is able, encourage the child to read the passage to you. Kindly correct their pronunciation.
Tell the child that there are some compound words in this passage. Model circling one of the compound words. Encourage the ch
ild to circle more – especially the words they have already learned. Point out all the compound words in the passage if the child doesn’t find them all

Sort the compound words that are inside or outside by drawing a line.
Model drawing a line from the toothbrush to the picture of the
I see a toothbrush inside the house.
Encourage the child to do the rest the same way.
Use the phrase with a compound word. Draw a line to the compound words you can eat.
while doing the action and have the child repeat.
Ask the child to draw a line from the boy eating to the compound w
ords he can eat. Say the complete phrases:
I am eating popcorn, I am eating pancakes, I am eating a cupcake.
Match the words in the box to make a compound word. Draw and write the name of the compound words in the three boxes below.
Then model drawing a ladybug in the first box and writing the compound word below it. Have the child do the same with the other two compound words.
Write the missing compound word on the lines.
Model reading and writing the missing compound word in the first sentence. Read the complete sentence. Have the child repeat the others in the same way.
Have the child repeat the others in the same way.
Write the compound word on the line after looking at the picture clues.
Ask the child what compound word that is. Encourage them to say
and write it on the line
Have the child complete the last two. Help them as needed by saying the names of the pictures.
Ask the child to circle the compound words. Help the child with words we haven’t learned yet.

Word Wall Vocabulary Builder Activity – Slide 22
